summary: This document is an email chain from April 2022 discussing T-Visa eligibility for an individual associated with the Jeffrey Epstein case. An FBI Victim Services Program Manager provides guidance that if the individual was not identified by the FBI as a victim, she is not eligible for a T visa. The chain includes communications between an FBI Victim Specialist, an attorney (Erica Dubno), and FBI agents regarding the individual's immigration status and prior denied requests.

persons.name: Erica T. Dubno
persons.context: Attorney representing an individual seeking a T-Visa related to the Jeffrey Epstein case; communicates with FBI personnel about the visa application process and requests documentation.

connections.description: Dubno communicates with FBI personnel M regarding T-Visa eligibility and victim status for her client.

events.title: T-Visa Eligibility Inquiry
events.description: An FBI Victim Specialist forwards an external email about a T-Visa application for an individual related to the Jeffrey Epstein case, noting prior denial of a request because she was not identified as a trafficking victim.

events.title: Visa Application Process Start
events.description: Erica Dubno notifies an FBI Special Agent that her client managed to get a stamp and is starting the visa application process, while also requesting a victim notification letter.

events.title: Immigration Attorney Referral Discussion
events.description: FBI personnel suggest connecting Dubno to a Legal Aid attorney who routinely works on T-Visa cases, as the FBI cannot advise on the best route.

locations: 43 West 43rd Street, Suite 261, New York, New York 10036
keyFacts: The FBI Victim Services Division states that if an individual was not identified by the FBI as a victim in the Epstein case, she is not eligible for a T visa.
A prior request for some form of immigration protection (CP) was denied by FBI HQ because the individual was not considered a trafficking victim.
Attorney Erica T. Dubno is assisting an individual related to the Jeffrey Epstein case with seeking a U or T visa for immigration status.
The email chain reveals ongoing communication between a victim's attorney and FBI personnel from 2020 to 2022 regarding immigration options.
The document highlights the procedural and eligibility challenges victims or associated individuals face in obtaining immigration benefits tied to the case.
